## GABA+Glx

GABA and Glx are fitted using a three-Gaussian model with a linear slope and non-linear baseline:

$$
S(\omega) =
\sum_{i=1}^{3}\left\{a_i\exp[g_i(\omega-\omega_i)^2]\right\}+
m(\omega-\omega_1)+
b_1\sin(\pi\omega/1.31/4)+
b_2\cos(\pi\omega/1.31/4)
$$

where:

| <u>Parameter</u> | <u>Definition</u> |
| :- | :-------- |
| $\omega$ | Frequency (ppm) |
| $a_i$ | Gaussian *i*'s amplitude |
| $g_i$ | Gaussian *i*'s width |
| $\omega_i$ | Gaussian *i*'s center frequency |
| $m$ | Slope of baseline |
| $b_1$ | Sine baseline term |
| $b_2$ | Cosine baseline term |

## GSH (TE < 100 ms)

GSH that is edited at a TE < 100 ms is fitted with a five-Gaussian model with a linear + quadratic baseline:

$$
S(\omega) =
\sum_{i=1}^{5}\left\{a_i\exp[g_i(\omega-\omega_i)^2]\right\}+
m_1(\omega-\omega_1)+b+
m_2(\omega-\omega_1)^2
$$

<img id="myImg2" src="images/signal-modeling/GSH-80.png" alt="Illustration of the GSH model at TE = 80 ms">

## GSH (TE >= 100 ms)

GSH that is edited at a TE >= 100 ms is fitted with a six-Gaussian model with a linear + quadratic baseline:

$$
S(\omega) =
\sum_{i=1}^{6}\left\{a_i\exp[g_i(\omega-\omega_i)^2]\right\}+
m_1(\omega-\omega_1)+b+
m_2(\omega-\omega_1)^2
$$

<img id="myImg2" src="images/signal-modeling/GSH-120.png" alt="Illustration of the GSH model at TE = 120 ms">
